study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of Orchid drug-coated balloon (DCB) versus percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) for treating femoropopliteal artery in-stent restenosis in Chinese patients, including functional outcomes like walking ability.
results_summary: The DCB group showed significantly higher primary patency (87.9% vs. 51.6%) and lower clinically-driven target-lesion revascularization rates (6.1% vs. 35.5%) at 12 months compared to PTA. Functional outcomes (WIQ, EQ-5D, 6MWT) were assessed, but specific walking-related results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Chinese patients with femoropopliteal artery in-stent restenosis (N=74).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how a stroke in young adults affects walking performance compared to healthy controls and determine if walking performance parameters predict return to employment poststroke.
results_summary: Stroke participants walked slower than healthy controls, but specific details on metabolic cost and other parameters were not fully provided in the abstract. The study suggests walking difficulties impact poststroke employment outcomes.
population_specificity: Young adults (18-65 years) who had a stroke and healthy age-matched controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess parent perceptions of a Walking School Bus (WSB) program to inform future interventions aimed at increasing walking to school and physical activity in children.
results_summary: Most parents supported the WSB program, citing benefits like improved child health, pedestrian safety, and positive adult interactions, though time constraints were a common barrier. Parents suggested improvements such as better recruitment and logistics.
population_specificity: Third- and fifth-grade students and their parents in the Seattle area.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether footwear, foot orthoses, and taping alter lower limb muscle activity during walking and running.
results_summary: The study found that rocker footwear decreases tibialis anterior activity and increases triceps surae activity during walking, while orthoses could reduce tibialis posterior activity and increase peroneus longus activity. Other footwear and taping effects were unclear.
population_specificity: Not specified (systematic review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of conducting a large-scale trial to compare the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a self-aligning prosthesis versus a standard prosthesis for older patients with transtibial amputations.
results_summary: The study is a feasibility trial, so no efficacy results are reported yet. It focuses on consent and retention rates, recruitment feasibility, and qualitative feedback on intervention acceptability.
population_specificity: Patients aged 50 years and over with transtibial amputations, mostly due to vascular-related or non-traumatic causes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between motor changes (including walking difficulties) and the development of oral mucositis in pediatric cancer patients undergoing antineoplastic treatment.
results_summary: The study found that individuals with severe difficulty in walking had a significantly higher likelihood of developing oral mucositis (OR: 25.42). Walking difficulties were identified as a contributing factor to oral mucositis in this population.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents aged 2 to 19 years diagnosed with any type of cancer and undergoing antineoplastic treatment in a pediatric hospital.
study_duration: Data collected from April to September 2017 (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility and acceptability of a health coaching intervention ("Walk this Way") to reduce sedentary behavior and increase physical activity in people with serious mental illness.
results_summary: The intervention reduced sedentary behavior by 56 minutes and increased total physical activity by 32 minutes per day, with effects sustained at 6-month follow-up. Participants found the intervention helpful and acceptable, with no adverse events reported.
population_specificity: People with serious mental illness (SMI) from three community mental health teams.
effective_dosage: Initial education session, fortnightly coaching, pedometer use, and access to a weekly walking group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate MSCopilot, a digital tool for self-assessment of MS-related disability, including walking, against the standard MSFC test.
results_summary: MSCopilot demonstrated non-inferior performance to MSFC in identifying MS patients versus healthy controls, with high sensitivity (81%) and specificity (82%). The digital and standard test scores were strongly correlated (r = 0.81).
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) and healthy controls (HCs).
study_duration: Single assessment at day 0, with reproducibility assessed at day 30 ± 3 for a subset.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety and efficacy of aerobic exercise (specifically treadmill-based physical fitness training) on activities of daily living and maximal walking speed in adults during the subacute phase after stroke.
results_summary: Aerobic physical fitness training did not significantly improve maximal walking speed or Barthel index scores compared to relaxation sessions at three months post-stroke. The aerobic group had a higher rate of serious adverse events, suggesting potential safety concerns.
population_specificity: Adults with subacute stroke (5-45 days post-stroke) and moderate to severe stroke severity (median NIHSS score of 8).
effective_dosage: 25 minutes, five times weekly for four weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and person-centeredness of rehabilitation activities, including walking, for persons with Parkinson's disease (PD) in home settings.
results_summary: Walking and other physical activities improved physical outcomes, quality of life, and daily living functions, especially when supported by digital devices, but cognitive and psychosocial rehabilitation were less researched.
population_specificity: Persons with Parkinson's disease (PD)

study_goal: To determine whether osteoarthritis (OA) and worse walking time are associated with incident social isolation in older adults.
results_summary: Worse walking time was significantly associated with increased risk of social isolation, alongside clinical OA, cognitive impairment, and depression. The study found that OA of the hip and/or knee, combined or not with hand OA, increased the risk of social isolation by 1.47 times.
population_specificity: Older people living in six European countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the implementation and effectiveness of "Pisando Fuerte," a culturally adapted fall prevention program for Hispanic/Latino individuals, based on the "Stepping On" program.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant improvement in falls behavioral risk (FaB score) and a non-significant decrease in falls. Most participants adopted safer walking strategies and continued exercises at 6 months, with results comparable to the original "Stepping On" program.
population_specificity: Hispanic/Latino individuals, primarily Spanish-speaking, with a mean age of 70.5 years (71% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of repeated 6-minute walk tests with immediate knowledge of results on walking capacity in patients with chronic hemiparesis, comparing fast and slow walkers.
results_summary: The study compared walking capacity between fast and slow walkers using repeated 6MWT with immediate feedback, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic hemiparesis.

study_goal: To investigate the effect of a 13-week exercise program on plantar pressure during walking in children with overweight/obesity.
results_summary: The exercise program led to increased maximum force under the forefoot, suggesting improved gait patterns, while the control group showed increased plantar surface area. No significant changes in force-time integrals were observed in either group.
population_specificity: Children (10.8 ± 1.2 years, 58.5% girls) with overweight/obesity.
effective_dosage: Not specified (13-week exercise program based on "movement quality" and "multigames").

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if gait parameters and clinical data could predict future fall risk among independent older adults using a supervised machine learning algorithm.
results_summary: The study developed a classification tree that correctly identified 80% of future fallers based on gait patterns, gender, and stiffness, with an accuracy of 84%, sensitivity of 80%, and specificity of 87%.
population_specificity: 105 adults aged >65 years, living independently at home without a recent fall history.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Tai Chi on pain and disability in patients with low back pain, including its impact on walking ability.
results_summary: The study found that Tai Chi significantly improved walking ability (WMD = -2.05, 95% CI -3.05 to -1.06, P < .0001, I² = 88%) among other functional disabilities in low back pain patients. The aggregated results showed consistent and statistically significant benefits across multiple disability measures.
population_specificity: Patients with low back pain (LBP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy of Integrated Qigong in improving gait parameters and reducing freezing of gait episodes in patients with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study protocol describes a randomized controlled trial comparing Integrated Qigong and balance training with a control group, but results are not yet available as it is a trial protocol.
population_specificity: Patients with mild to moderate Parkinson's disease who experience freezing of gait, recruited from local communities in Shanghai, China.
effective_dosage: Integrated Qigong and balance training groups: 60-minute sessions, 3 times per week for 12 weeks; control group: 60-minute weekly sessions plus monthly health education.

study_goal: To establish the reliability and validity of the Rivermead Visual Gait Assessment (RVGA) for assessing gait deviations in post-stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found good-to-excellent inter-rater reliability and acceptable validity for RVGA when correlated with other gait and balance measures, suggesting it is a reliable and valid tool for assessing post-stroke gait impairments.
population_specificity: 40 chronic stroke patients.
study_duration: Assessments were conducted at baseline and after 1 month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of over-ground robotic locomotor training in improving walking performance, cardiovascular demands, secondary health complications, and user-satisfaction in individuals with spinal cord injuries.
results_summary: Most studies reported decreases in exertion ratings, pain, and spasticity, along with positive well-being post-intervention. Meta-analyses showed significant improvements in walking performance (6-min walking test, 10-metre walking test, and Timed Up and Go Test), though no significant cardiovascular changes were observed.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injuries (308 participants across 27 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether immersive virtual reality (IVR) simulating high-intensity intermittent aerobic exercise (HIE) could improve cognitive executive functions and induce physiological responses similar to actual walking, despite the participant remaining physically still.
results_summary: The study found that IVR-induced HIE in first-person perspective (1PP) could produce physiological reactions (e.g., increased heart rate) and potentially improve executive functions, as measured by the Stroop task and cortical hemodynamic changes via fNIRS. The effects were compared to a third-person perspective (3PP) control condition, with 1PP showing stronger illusory ownership and agency over the virtual body.
population_specificity: 30 healthy young adults
effective_dosage: Eight sets of 30 seconds of virtual running followed by 30 seconds of slow walking
study_duration: One week apart for IVR sessions

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of water-walking versus land-walking on body composition in inactive older adults over a 24-week period.
results_summary: Both water-walking and land-walking reduced central adiposity, with water-walking also increasing lower limb lean mass, but these benefits did not persist after the intervention ended. No significant changes in body mass or BMI were observed.
population_specificity: Healthy but inactive older adults (mean age 62.5±6.8 years).
effective_dosage: 3 times/week at matched intensity (40-45% to 55-65% heart rate reserve).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether post-operative walking time, along with other variables, predicts substantial improvement in physical function six months after lumbar surgery.
results_summary: Participants who walked more in the first post-operative week were more likely to have substantially improved function at six months. Other predictors of improved function included shorter pre-operative pain duration, lower pre-operative function, and younger age.
population_specificity: Adults undergoing lumbar surgery (discectomy, decompression, fusion).
study_duration: Walking time was measured in the first post-operative week; outcomes were assessed at six months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the acceptability and feasibility of using wearable activity trackers (Fitbit ZipTM) and different reporting methods for walking among older adults with chronic musculoskeletal pain, and whether tracker use improved functioning and activity.
results_summary: Over 90% of participants found the trackers easy to use, though some faced technical or dexterity issues. Text message reporting had the highest adherence (79%). However, intervention participants did not show greater improvements in functioning or walking compared to controls.
population_specificity: 51 African American adults aged 60-85 years with chronic musculoskeletal pain in a low-income, urban community (Detroit, Michigan).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of exercise (including walking as part of aerobic exercise) and nutrition on body composition, metabolic health, and physical performance in individuals with sarcopenic obesity.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise (which includes walking) decreased body weight and fat mass, while the combination of aerobic and resistance exercise improved walking speed. Nutritional intervention alone did not improve physical performance.
population_specificity: Individuals with sarcopenic obesity (low muscle mass and high body fat).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of customized insoles with metatarsal and arch support in relieving walking pain and improving function in patients with Morton's neuroma.
results_summary: The study found that customized insoles significantly reduced walking pain and improved patient-reported functional measures compared to flat insoles. Secondary outcomes, including pain at rest, palpation, and paresthesia, also showed improvement in the experimental group.
population_specificity: 72 outpatients with Morton's neuroma from a university hospital setting.
effective_dosage: Not specified (customized insole with metatarsal and arch support vs. flat insole, both made of ethyl vinyl acetate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immediate effect of a horse riding simulator (HRS) on reducing adductor spasticity and improving hip abduction range of motion in children with spastic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The HRS group showed significant reduction in adductor spasticity and improvement in hip abduction range of motion post-intervention, while the control group showed no difference. HRS was effective in reducing spasticity and enhancing mobility in children with spastic CP.
population_specificity: Children with spastic cerebral palsy (24 participants, divided into experimental and control groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a multicomponent home-based physical therapy intervention versus an active control in restoring community walking ability in older adults after hip fracture.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant improvement in the ability to walk 300 m or more in 6 minutes after 16 weeks between the training group and the active control group. Adverse events were similar between groups, with falls being the most common.
population_specificity: Adults aged 60+ who had a hip fracture, lived in the community, and were previously able to walk without assistance.
effective_dosage: 2-3 home visits weekly for 16 weeks, plus daily vitamin D (2000 IU), calcium (600 mg), and multivitamins.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of HABIT-ILE (a novel intensive motor intervention integrating upper and lower extremity training) to usual care in improving gross motor function, manual ability, walking endurance, mobility, self-care, and quality of life in children with bilateral cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study assessed primary outcomes (Gross Motor Function Measure and ABILHAND-Kids) and secondary outcomes (walking endurance, mobility, etc.), but specific results regarding walking endurance or mobility improvements were not detailed in the abstract. The abstract indicates that outcomes were measured at baseline, post-intervention, and 26 weeks, suggesting a focus on retention of effects.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-16 years with bilateral cerebral palsy.
effective_dosage: 6.5 hours per day for 10 days (total 65 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of prescribed pulmonary exercises (modified from traditional Chinese exercises) on exercise capacity and quality of life in stable COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in upper and lower limb exercise capacity, endurance, and quality of life in COPD patients after 3 months of prescribed pulmonary exercises. The results were statistically significant (p < 0.05).
population_specificity: Stable COPD patients
effective_dosage: 60 minutes twice per day, 7 days a week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate validated screening tools for identifying sarcopenia risk in community-dwelling older adults and assess their performance against international diagnostic criteria.
results_summary: The review identified 6 candidate screening tools, with SARC-F showing high specificity but low sensitivity. Combining SARC-F with calf circumference improved sensitivity and diagnostic performance. Equation-based anthropometric tools performed well but require external validation.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults at risk of sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical outcomes in patients with post-procedural tricuspid valve gradient (TVG) >3 mmHg versus ≤3 mmHg after transcatheter edge-to-edge tricuspid valve repair (TTVR).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in device success, clinical improvement (including NYHA class and six-minute walking test), mortality, or hospitalization for heart failure between patients with TVG >3 mmHg and those with TVG ≤3 mmHg. Elevated TVG had no impact on outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with severe tricuspid regurgitation (TR) treated with TTVR (n=145).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical intervention, not a supplement).
study_duration: Outcomes assessed at one month and one year post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether perioperative non-surgical interventions, including walking training, could prevent long-term pain after total knee replacement (TKR) in adults with osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found a suggestion of clinically important benefit from walking training (one study) in reducing long-term pain after TKR, though definitive conclusions were limited due to intervention heterogeneity and the small number of studies. No concerns relating to long-term adverse events were reported for walking training.
population_specificity: Adults with osteoarthritis receiving primary total knee replacement.

study_goal: To determine the acute effect of indacaterol and tiotropium on walking distance and dyspnea during the six-minute walking test in moderate COPD associated with biomass exposure.
results_summary: Both indacaterol and tiotropium showed significant and fast-onset improvement in hyperinflation, walking distance, and dyspnea during the six-minute walking test. The improvements were observed at 30, 60, and 240 minutes post-drug administration.
population_specificity: Forty-two women with moderate COPD associated with biomass exposure.
effective_dosage: Indacaterol 150 μg once daily, tiotropium 18 μg once daily.
study_duration: Acute effects measured at 30, 60, and 240 minutes post-drug administration (crossover trial design).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether providing visual feedback about physical activity (including walking) increased the time hospitalized patients spent out of bed.
results_summary: The study found no overall significant increase in time out of bed with visual feedback, but a subgroup of patients with independent mobility spent 51 more minutes out of bed when given feedback.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients admitted to a pulmonary ward.
study_duration: Median length of stay was 5 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine differences in gait, balance, mobility, and muscle strength between individuals with anxiety and healthy controls, and to investigate the relationship between anxiety levels and motor characteristics.
results_summary: Participants with anxiety exhibited slower walking speed, shorter step length, fewer steps per minute, balance deficiencies, and mobility dysfunction compared to controls. Women with anxiety also showed significantly lower muscle strength than healthy women.
population_specificity: 93 participants (48 with anxiety, 45 healthy controls), ages 18-65, both genders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether home-based physical activity interventions, such as walking programs, are effective in improving physical activity and other outcomes among breast cancer patients undergoing primary therapy.
results_summary: Home-based walking programs showed positive effects on physical functioning and symptoms like fatigue in breast cancer patients. They were particularly effective in reducing symptoms and improving physical functioning among women receiving adjuvant chemotherapy or radiation therapy.
population_specificity: Women undergoing primary therapy for breast cancer, including those receiving adjuvant chemotherapy or radiation therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of using smartphone apps and smart bands to collect physical activity data and investigate its correlation with distress levels in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study found that smartphone apps had higher compliance rates (88.0%) compared to smart bands (52.5%), and step counts from smart bands showed a significant correlation with distress levels. Compliance rates for smart bands decreased significantly over time, while smartphone apps maintained higher adherence.
population_specificity: Female breast cancer survivors who underwent surgery at Asan Medical Center, Seoul, Republic of Korea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of wearable sensors for sensitive, objective, and easy-to-use assessment of community ambulation in persons with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: The study found that wearable technology can provide comprehensive measures of gait in PwMS but is under-studied compared to other populations. Current research lacks exploration of gait asymmetry and complexity in free-living conditions.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (PwMS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between pelvic stability during walking, clinical parameters, and surgical outcomes in patients with degenerative lumbar spinal stenosis (DLSS).
results_summary: The study found that greater pelvic rigidity during walking may act as a compensatory mechanism to reduce pain by keeping the spinal canal more open. Body mass index, but not symptom duration, muscle atrophy, or stenosis grade, explained changes in disability scores post-surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic degenerative lumbar spinal stenosis (DLSS) scheduled for decompression surgery.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on walking mechanics, not a supplement).
study_duration: Assessments were conducted pre-surgery, 10 weeks postoperatively, and 12 months postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a daily 12,000-step strategy with or without moderate-intensity walking exercise on body composition and metabolic syndrome in obese college students.
results_summary: The study found that combining a walking exercise program with a daily step goal significantly improved hip circumference and visceral fat area, while merely setting a step goal did not yield improvements. The combination strategy was deemed more time-efficient for enhancing body composition and metabolic syndrome markers.
population_specificity: College students with obesity (mean age 19.72 years, BMI 30.38 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 12,000 steps per day with or without moderate-intensity walking exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the challenges of anticoagulation in patients with chronic kidney disease, focusing on bleeding and thrombosis risks, and provide clinical recommendations.
results_summary: The study summarized existing evidence on anticoagulation use for stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation and discussed practical considerations for patients with advanced kidney disease or on dialysis.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced chronic kidney disease (estimated glomerular filtration rate ≤ 30 mL/min) or those receiving dialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of diurnal exercise timing (morning vs. evening) on glycemic control and circadian rhythm of wrist skin temperature in overweight adults with and without type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The 12-week multimodal exercise program improved glycemic control in both groups, but no significant differences were found between morning and evening exercise. The circadian rhythm of skin temperature was not altered by exercise timing.
population_specificity: Sedentary, overweight adults (mean age 51 ± 13 years, BMI 30.9 ± 4.2 kg/m²) with and without type 2 diabetes (n=20 with T2D, n=20 without).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of moderate-intensity walking plus 4 resistance-based exercises (3 sets, 12-18 repetitions each), 3 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and potential effects of an augmented prescribed exercise program (APEP) on mobility capacity in older acute medical patients.
results_summary: The study found that APEP was safe and feasible, with no severe adverse events, but no statistically significant differences in mobility outcomes were observed. A larger sample size would be needed to detect potential small to moderate effects on mobility.
population_specificity: Older acute medical patients (age ≥ 65 years) with walking ability, excluding those with severe cognitive impairment or medical restrictions for exercise.
study_duration: Until hospital discharge (specific duration not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of the Genium knee on ambulation, mobility, activities of daily living (ADLs), and quality of life compared to standard microprocessor-controlled prosthetic knees (MPKs) in transfemoral amputees.
results_summary: The study found that transitioning to the Genium knee resulted in more physiological and symmetric gait, reduced compensatory motions, and significant improvements in mobility, ADLs, and quality of life. The evidence was medium to high in validity, supporting the benefits of the Genium knee over conventional MPKs.
population_specificity: Transfemoral amputees (TFAs), primarily active subjects (MFCL-3/4) transitioning from C-Leg to Genium knee systems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the evidence quality of trials using vestibular rehabilitation exercises to improve postural control, balance, and gait in children with sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL).
results_summary: The systematic review found promising but low-quality evidence that vestibular rehabilitation exercises improve postural control, balance, and gait in children with SNHL, though methodological limitations warrant cautious interpretation.
population_specificity: Children up to 12 years old with SNHL and vestibular dysfunction, excluding those with physical, cognitive, or neurological impairments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of motor-cognitive training using Xbox Kinect on cognitive and motor aspects in individuals with Parkinson's disease (PD) and older adults without PD.
results_summary: The study found significant cognitive improvements in both groups (measured by Montreal Cognitive Assessment and FAB), but no retention on FAB in the PD group. No significant motor improvements were observed in either group.
population_specificity: Eight individuals with PD (mean age 68.9 ± 7.9) and eight age-matched older adults without PD (mean age 67.6 ± 7.3).
effective_dosage: Ten sessions of six Xbox 360 Kinect games (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Duration not explicitly stated, but involved ten sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of percutaneous mesenchymal stem cell injections for treating knee osteoarthritis, focusing on clinical and functional outcomes.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain, function, and walking distance at 6- and 12-month follow-ups, with a 12.7% rate of local complications. Patients at earlier degeneration stages showed greater improvements.
population_specificity: Adults with idiopathic knee osteoarthritis (mean age 57.39 ± 7.37 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically assess the effectiveness of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) on gait improvement in individuals with Parkinson disease (PD).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that rTMS improved walking time in the short term but not in the long term, with no significant differences in the Timed Up and Go (TUG) test or freezing of gait questionnaire scores between rTMS and control groups. Significant improvements were observed during the "on-state" but not the "off-state" of PD medication.
population_specificity: Individuals diagnosed with idiopathic Parkinson disease (mean age 63.24±9.71 years, 64% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether a rehabilitation program involving Nordic walking (NW), occupational therapy (OT), and therapeutic touch (TT) improves motor and non-motor outcomes in PD patients and whether the timing of OT within the program affects results.
results_summary: The study found improvements in 6MWT, gait speed, gait length, UPDRS II and III, FAB, and PDQ39 scores over time, with no significant differences based on OT timing. Baseline UPDRS II and III scores significantly predicted improvements in gait metrics.
population_specificity: 17 PD patients (13 analyzed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a physiotherapist-led behavioral change intervention (MOSAIC) on walking ability in adults with intermittent claudication compared to usual care.
results_summary: The study assessed walking ability (6-minute walking distance) at 3 and 6 months, with outcomes measured by a blinded assessor. Results were analyzed using intention-to-treat regression adjusted for baseline and center, but specific efficacy findings are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥50 with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and intermittent claudication, recruited from six NHS Hospital Trusts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the diurnal influences on gastric emptying rate, metabolic responses, and appetite during fasted and non-fasted walking.
results_summary: The study compared morning and evening walks under fasted and fed conditions, measuring gastric emptying rate and metabolic responses, but specific results regarding walking's effects were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Twelve healthy males.
effective_dosage: Four 45-minute walks (morning and evening, fasted or fed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare surgical outcomes for osteoporotic vertebral fracture (OVF) in the thoracolumbar spine, focusing on neurological symptoms and functional improvement in walking ability.
results_summary: All five surgical procedures resulted in acceptable neurological outcomes and functional improvement in walking ability, with similar complication rates and mechanical failure prevalence. The APSF and 3CO groups showed greater local kyphosis correction, while the VP + PSF group had lower intraoperative blood loss.
population_specificity: 315 OVF patients (mean age 74 years; 68 men and 247 women) with neurological symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of treadmill training (Walking) in patients with Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT1A) neuropathy compared to stretching and proprioceptive exercise alone.
results_summary: Most patients showed improvement in walking and balance assessments after 3 and 6 months of treatment, with no reported adverse events or deterioration in motor performance. The study concluded that both interventions provided objective benefits without causing overwork weakness.
population_specificity: Outpatients affected by Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease type 1A (CMT1A).
effective_dosage: Not specified (treadmill training as part of TreSPE regimen).
study_duration: 6 months (assessed at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the short-term and long-term effects of a tailored, home-based brisk walking program on reducing fatigue in breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The walking program reduced fatigue in the exercise group compared to the control group, with the effect lasting beyond the intervention period. Fatigue levels fluctuated with functional performance, sleep disturbance, and depression.
population_specificity: Women diagnosed with stages I-III breast cancer experiencing insomnia, fatigue, pain, or depressive symptoms after their first cycle of chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 12-week home-based brisk walking program (specific frequency/intensity not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of osteopathic treatment combined with conventional pharmacological therapy in improving quality of life and functional outcomes (e.g., 6MWT) in patients with moderate-to-severe COPD.
results_summary: Patients receiving osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) alongside conventional therapy showed significant improvements in the 6-minute walking test (6MWT) and COPD Assessment Test (CAT) scores compared to controls, indicating better functional capacity and quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with stable moderate-to-severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of percutaneous full-endoscopic anterior transcorporeal cervical diskectomy in treating migrated cervical disk herniation and its impact on walking instability.
results_summary: The procedure improved the patient's Japanese Orthopaedic Association (JOA) score from 8 to 16 points over 2 years, with an 88.9% improvement rate, and imaging confirmed healing without complications.
population_specificity: A 42-year-old man with migrated cervical disk herniation causing nuchal pain, limb numbness, and unstable walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize associations between altered lower extremity joint moments and altered trunk dynamics in persons with unilateral transtibial amputation during walking.
results_summary: The study found that persons with transtibial amputation exhibited greater trunk angular acceleration induced by the prosthetic ankle and reduced knee extensor moments, leading to altered trunk dynamics compared to uninjured individuals. These findings suggest kinetic compensations at joints other than the lumbar and hip contribute to altered trunk motion.
population_specificity: 10 persons with unilateral transtibial amputation and 10 uninjured persons.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of surgical (laminectomy) versus non-surgical (structured physical training program) treatments for symptomatic lumbar spinal stenosis, including evaluating walking ability as a tertiary outcome.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of walking, as the study is described as ongoing or not yet concluded.
population_specificity: 150 patients with symptomatic lumbar spinal stenosis.
study_duration: 6 months (follow-up period mentioned for blood sample analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and effects of a 6-week preoperative rehabilitation program (including walking) on functional capacity in patients with lumbar spinal stenosis.
results_summary: The intervention group showed improvements in active ranges of motion, leg pain intensity, lumbar extensor muscle endurance, and walking capacities. The study reported no adverse events and high adherence, suggesting feasibility for a full-scale trial.
population_specificity: Patients with lumbar spinal stenosis preparing for surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the individual and combined contributions of intensity and variability of stepping practice to improving walking speed and distance in individuals poststroke.
results_summary: High-intensity stepping training resulted in significantly greater improvements in walking ability and gait symmetry compared to low-intensity training, with additional gains in spatiotemporal symmetry and balance confidence observed in specific subgroups.
population_specificity: Individuals between 18 and 85 years old with hemiparesis poststroke of >6 months duration.
effective_dosage: Up to 30 sessions over 2 months, with high-intensity stepping (70%-80% heart rate reserve) or low-intensity stepping (30%-40% heart rate reserve).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether consumer behavior towards footwear is a risk factor for lower extremity injuries in leisure-time walkers and runners.
results_summary: The study found that undergoing a gait analysis before buying shoes was associated with an increased occurrence of lower extremity injuries, while caring a lot about the right fitting of shoes was protective. 24% of subjects suffered a lower extremity injury, with runners experiencing more injuries than walkers.
population_specificity: Leisure-time walkers and runners (104 walkers and 104 runners).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether individual cardiovascular markers at rest could predict clinical outcomes of walking as an intervention for IBS symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that higher resting baroreceptor sensitivity (BRS) was associated with decreased pain severity in the walking group, suggesting walking may be more effective for individuals with higher BRS. Other cardiovascular measures also showed associations with clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: 27 adult participants with Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a rehabilitative program combining conventional therapy with early overground body weight-support training in improving independent walking for subacute stroke patients.
results_summary: The experimental group showed a statistically significant increase in independent walking (measured by FAC) compared to the control group, but no differences were observed in other functional mobility, disability, or gait endurance outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with subacute hemiparesis (stroke within 4 weeks) and significant gait deficiencies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of balloon pulmonary angioplasty (BPA) in improving hemodynamic and functional status in patients with inoperable chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH) despite having lesions suitable for surgical treatment.
results_summary: BPA significantly improved mean pulmonary artery pressure, pulmonary vascular resistance, arterial oxygen saturation, and 6-minute walking distance in patients with inoperable CTEPH, including those with lesions suitable for surgery but not operated on. However, multiple BPA sessions were required for these improvements.
population_specificity: Patients with inoperable chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH), including those with lesions suitable for surgical treatment but not operated on (n=43, age 62.6±13.5 years, 31 women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of inertial measurement units (IMUs) as a reliable biomarker for assessing gait impairment and disease severity in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients.
results_summary: IMU-measured gait parameters (speed, step length, and step time) were significantly correlated with disease severity scales (EDSS and MSWS-12), suggesting IMUs can enhance sensitivity in detecting gait alterations in MS patients with low to medium disability.
population_specificity: Multiple sclerosis (MS) patients, particularly those with low to medium Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) scores (1.0-4.5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the consistency of a triad involving late-life depression, executive dysfunction, and impaired gait speed, and explore potential shared brain mechanisms.
results_summary: The triad was supported by 80% of included studies, with a reported prevalence of 17% in one population study. Mixed results were found regarding intervention benefits, and vascular risk factors were commonly associated with the triad.
population_specificity: Adults over age 65 with assessments of mood, executive function, and gait speed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of combining an endothelin receptor antagonist and a phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor on pulmonary arterial hypertension, focusing on clinical worsening, 6-minute walking distance, pulmonary vascular resistance, and N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide.
results_summary: The combination therapy significantly improved 6-minute walking distance, reduced clinical worsening, and lowered N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide levels compared to monotherapy, but showed no significant improvement in pulmonary vascular resistance.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether multidisciplinary rehabilitation, including walking function improvement, could enhance motor functional recovery in patients with neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder.
results_summary: The multidisciplinary rehabilitation group showed significant improvements in walking function and other motor functions after 4 weeks, with sustained benefits in walking ability observed after 3 months. The control group also showed some improvement in walking ability but no significant changes in other variables.
population_specificity: 39 patients with neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder and moderate to severe disability.
effective_dosage: Multidisciplinary rehabilitation 5 times/week for 4 weeks, followed by community- or home-based rehabilitation for 3 months.
study_duration: 4 weeks of hospital-based intervention, followed by 3 months of follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of interventions using activity trackers on physical activity, mobility, quality of life, and mental health among people aged 60+ years.
results_summary: Interventions using activity trackers had a moderate effect on physical activity and improved mobility among older people compared with control, but the impact on quality of life and mental health remains unknown.
population_specificity: People aged 60+ years

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of aerobic programs, similar in activity and dosage to cardiac rehabilitation, for improving aerobic and walking capacity in stroke survivors.
results_summary: Stroke survivors showed improved composite aerobic capacity with an effect size of 0.38, and studies including the 6-minute walk test demonstrated a pooled mean difference of 53.3 meters. Follow-up data were inconclusive.
population_specificity: Survivors of stroke

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of riociguat in patients with pulmonary hypertension associated with idiopathic interstitial pneumonia (PH-IIP).
results_summary: The study found that riociguat did not improve 6-minute walking distance compared to placebo and was associated with increased serious adverse events and mortality. The risk-benefit profile was deemed unfavorable, leading to early termination of the study.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-80 with idiopathic interstitial pneumonia, forced vital capacity ≥45%, 6MWD of 150-450 m, WHO functional classes II-IV, and precapillary pulmonary hypertension confirmed by right heart catheterization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of exercise training, including walking, on physical fitness outcomes such as aerobic capacity, walking capacity, and health-related quality of life in adults with end-stage renal disease undergoing hemodialysis.
results_summary: The study found that various exercise types, including aerobic and combined exercises, improved aerobic capacity, walking capacity, and health-related quality of life in the studied population. Aerobic and combined exercises were particularly effective.
population_specificity: Adults with end-stage renal disease undergoing hemodialysis.
effective_dosage: 3 times weekly (specific walking dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the usefulness and limitations of the 6-minute walking test (6MWT) in assessing functional capacity and prognosis in patients with heart failure (HF).
results_summary: The study found that the 6MWT provides reliable information about daily activity in HF patients and can be a useful tool in clinical practice, though it is not as comprehensive as maximal exercise tests. It also identified associations between 6MWT results and other functional measures, as well as its prognostic role.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure (HF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of endurance training (including walking) and resistance training on physical fitness, psychological well-being, sleep, and quality of life in high-grade glioma patients post-treatment.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding walking's effects, as the study is described as ongoing or not yet concluded.
population_specificity: Patients with high-grade glioma (WHO grade III and IV) after neurosurgery and adjuvant radiotherapy, chemotherapy, or chemoradiotherapy.
effective_dosage: 2 weekly sessions of 30-45 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety, efficacy, and tolerability of bimagrumab in individuals with inclusion body myositis, focusing on its impact on 6-minute walking distance (6MWD).
results_summary: Bimagrumab did not improve 6MWD compared to placebo, with no significant differences observed across dosage groups. The treatment showed a good safety profile but was associated with frequent adverse events, including falls, muscle spasms, and diarrhea.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 36-85 years with inclusion body myositis.
effective_dosage: 10 mg/kg, 3 mg/kg, or 1 mg/kg administered intravenously every 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal timing of walking and other physical activities relative to meal ingestion for improving postprandial blood glucose control.
results_summary: Walking immediately after a meal significantly improved mean, coefficient of variance, and area under the curve for glucose compared to the control, while walking before or 30 minutes after the meal had no significant effect. The study suggests that low- to moderate-intensity activity, including walking, is most effective when performed soon after eating.
population_specificity: 48 adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize and evaluate the existing scientific evidence on the effects of Nordic walking on women with breast cancer, focusing on methodological quality and outcomes.
results_summary: Nordic walking had a significant positive impact on breast cancer symptoms, including lymphedema, physical fitness, disability, and morbid perceptions, with no reported adverse effects. However, methodological limitations in the studies suggest the need for further research.
population_specificity: Women with breast cancer (BC survivors).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if gait parameters in patients with axial spondyloarthritis (axSpA) could predict physical function at 18 months, as measured by the Bath Ankylosing Spondylitis Functional Index (BASFI).
results_summary: The study proposes that combining clinical and laboratory gait measurements in axSpA patients could improve disease monitoring and predict changes in physical function, potentially enabling timely, personalized interventions. Results are pending as data collection is ongoing.
population_specificity: 60 patients with axSpA (aged 18-65) and 30 healthy age- and sex-matched controls.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (gait analysis, not a supplement).
study_duration: 18 months (with assessments at baseline, 6, 12, and 18 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of different levels of energy turnover (physical activity and corresponding energy intake) on glucose metabolism under varying energy balance conditions (zero energy balance, caloric restriction, and overfeeding).
results_summary: Higher energy turnover (physical activity) did not increase daylong glycemia or insulin secretion, and under caloric restriction, it reduced both. Postprandial glucose and insulin levels were lower with higher energy turnover during caloric restriction and overfeeding.
population_specificity: 16 healthy individuals (13 men, 3 women; age 25.1 ± 3.9 years; BMI 24.0 ± 3.2 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: Not specified (low, medium, and high levels of physical activity were compared).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the usefulness of COPD subtypes identified through cluster analysis to predict the first acute exacerbation (AE) in COPD patients.
results_summary: The study identified four COPD clusters (putative asthma-COPD overlap, mild COPD, moderate COPD, and severe COPD subtypes), with the ACO group showing the second-best post-BD FEV. The analysis revealed an exacerbator subtype of COPD independent of FEV.
population_specificity: COPD patients from the Korea COPD Subgroup Study (KOCOSS) cohort (n=1,195 with follow-up data for AE).

study_goal: The researchers were comparing the clinical and physiological characteristics of pleuroparenchymal fibroelastosis (PPFE) to idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), including differences in walking distance.
results_summary: The study found that PPFE patients showed a mild decrease in walking distance despite a markedly decreased forced vital capacity (FVC), unlike IPF patients.
population_specificity: Patients with pleuroparenchymal fibroelastosis (PPFE) and idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a resistance training program on metabolic syndrome markers in patients with morbid obesity compared to obese peers.
results_summary: Resistance training improved metabolic syndrome outcomes (waist circumference, blood pressure, and plasma triglycerides) more in morbidly obese patients than in obese peers, with no significant differences in non-responder prevalence.
population_specificity: Adults with obesity (BMI ≥35 <40 kg/m²) or morbid obesity (BMI ≥40 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the Auditory Stroop Task (AST) could increase cognitive load and elicit freezing of gait (FOG) in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients, while also testing if visual cues could counteract these effects.
results_summary: The AST negatively affected gait parameters in both PD patients and healthy controls but did not increase FOG occurrence. Visual cues mitigated some of the stride length decline caused by cognitive load.
population_specificity: 19 healthy elderly subjects (Experiment 1), 20 PD patients with FOG, and 18 healthy controls (Experiment 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare metabolic demand and muscle activity during sedentary behavior and light physical activities (including walking) among healthy controls, adults with stroke, and adults with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: Walking increased electromyographic values in people with severe stroke or CP, reaching values above 1.5 METs, indicating higher metabolic demand and muscle activity compared to sedentary positions.
population_specificity: 71 adults (18 healthy controls, 31 with stroke, 22 with CP), aged 18-86.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize interventions, including therapeutic walking, for suicide prevention in cancer patients and highlight methodological issues.
results_summary: The study found little evidence to confirm the effects of suicide prevention strategies, including therapeutic walking, with most trials demonstrating inadequate quality. Suicidal behavior or ideation was reported as a secondary outcome, but no specific efficacy was noted for walking.
population_specificity: Patients with cancer

study_goal: To determine whether functional electrical stimulation (FES) during walking improves ischemic pain and quality of life in patients with diabetic arteriopathy (DA) in grade-IIa Leriche-Le Fontaine.
results_summary: Both diabetic and nondiabetic groups reported improvement after FES-assisted walking, with statistically significant improvements in the diabetic group across all studied parameters except for the 6-minute walk test. Greater benefits were observed in the diabetic group after follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients with grade-IIa Leriche-Le Fontaine peripheral arterial disease in both lower extremities, with and without diabetes mellitus (DM).
effective_dosage: 1 hour of supervised treadmill walking with FES.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Clinical Pilates training versus home exercise training on walking endurance, balance, and other functional outcomes in persons with multiple sclerosis (pwMS).
results_summary: Clinical Pilates training showed superior improvements in walking endurance, postural stability, core stability, respiratory, and cognitive functions compared to home exercise training, though no significant differences were found in walking speed, perceived walking ability, or fear of falling.
population_specificity: Forty-two persons with multiple sclerosis (pwMS).
effective_dosage: Pilates exercises weekly for 8 weeks plus a home exercise program; home exercise group received standardized exercises.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare muscle architecture, mass, and strength in hospitalized older adults with different functional levels and evaluate associations between these measurements.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in relative muscle strength, pennation angle, and muscle thickness between disabled and pre-disabled groups, with muscle architecture related to functional capacity. Ultrasound was suggested as a potential tool for assessing physical decline.
population_specificity: Hospitalized older adults (44 participants, divided into pre-disabled and disabled groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of robot-assisted gait training and treadmill training on endurance, gait capacity, and quality of life in people with Parkinson's disease, particularly those with freezing of gait or severe gait disability.
results_summary: Both robot-assisted gait training and treadmill training significantly improved endurance, gait capacity, motor symptoms, and quality of life, with robot-assisted training showing greater benefits for individuals with freezing of gait. The Freezing of Gait Questionnaire score decreased by 20% after either treatment, and dependent walkers benefited more than independent walkers.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease (Hoehn and Yahr stage ≥2), including those with freezing of gait and/or severe gait disability.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied to be over the course of 20 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility of a physiotherapy intervention designed to improve muscle strength, posture, and joint use during walking and everyday activities in young children with haemophilia.
results_summary: The study will assess safety, adherence, recruitment, retention, and clinical outcomes, including muscle strength and joint biomechanics during walking, but results are not yet reported.
population_specificity: Young children with haemophilia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if onboard sensors alone could identify user intent for gait speed changes in robotic exoskeletons, comparing able-bodied and non-able-bodied users.
results_summary: The study found that joint positions and commanded motor currents significantly differed following intent changes, suggesting onboard sensors can detect gait intent, though signals depend on control settings, user ability, and timing.
population_specificity: Able-bodied and non-able-bodied users of robotic exoskeletons.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify ankle impedance during walking in individuals post-stroke, compare it to healthy populations, and assess its relationship with clinical outcome measures.
results_summary: The study found that the paretic ankle showed reduced stiffness variation during mid-stance and increased damping during early and mid-stance compared to healthy individuals. Clinical measures from dynamic tasks strongly correlated with stiffness changes, while passive measures did not.
population_specificity: Four individuals post-stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety and feasibility of a walking program for women with metastatic breast cancer and explore its efficacy.
results_summary: Adherence to the walking program was poor (25%), but no adverse events were reported. Preliminary data suggested potential improvements in physical capacity, though efficacy was not strongly demonstrated.
population_specificity: Women with metastatic breast cancer

study_goal: The researchers sought to examine the effects of aquatic walking exercise on cardiovascular function and cardiorespiratory capacity in individuals with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The abstract suggests that aquatic walking exercise may improve cardiovascular function and cardiorespiratory capacity, though specific results are not detailed. The study implies potential benefits for mitigating PAD-related health declines.
population_specificity: Individuals with peripheral artery disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the sensitivity of inertial motion capture (IMC) compared to optical motion capture (OMC) in detecting small changes in gait during treadmill walking, simulating recovery of hemiparetic gait.
results_summary: The study found that IMC could detect a gait speed difference of 0.08 m/s, roughly equivalent to two weeks of recovery progress, and showed a strong trend of being more sensitive to gait changes than OMC, though statistical significance was not conclusively established.
population_specificity: Eight unimpaired individuals.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study involved treadmill walking conditions, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of three different eye-tracking paradigms in differentiating autistic and typically developing children and their sensitivity to specific autistic symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that the dancing people versus dynamic geometry paradigm was the most effective in differentiating autistic children, who showed reduced visual preference for social stimuli and increased preference for geometric patterns, correlating with social affect symptoms.
population_specificity: Young (2-7 years old) Chinese autistic (n = 35) and typically developing (n = 34) children matched for age and gender.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the association between muscle characteristics (e.g., sarcopenia) and cerebral grey matter volumes in older people with type 2 diabetes, focusing on functional and nutritional assessments.
results_summary: The study found that frail subjects had lower nutritional and functional scores, and muscle strength was correlated with grey matter volumes involved in motor control. Walking time was negatively associated with grey matter volumes in motor areas, while rising chair performance was positively associated.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 78.2 years) with type 2 diabetes, including frail and pre-frail individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between socio-economic status (SES) and clinical presentation, risk factors, and exposure to STEC infection, including environmental exposures such as walking in a paddock.
results_summary: The study found that advantaged individuals were more likely to report environmental exposures like walking in a paddock (OR 1.82, 95% CI 1.22-2.70), suggesting potential differences in risk behaviors or unmeasured transmission factors between SES groups.
population_specificity: All STEC cases identified in England from 2010-2015, stratified by socio-economic status.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-impact daily physical activity, specifically walking, could improve sleep quality and duration in healthy middle-aged and older adults.
results_summary: The study found that daily active minutes were positively related to sleep quality but not duration, with women showing a stronger benefit than men. On days participants were more active than average, they reported better sleep quality and duration in both sexes.
population_specificity: 59 participants (72% female) from the greater Boston area, average age 49.43 (±8.40) years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention aimed at increasing daily steps).

study_goal: To investigate the efficacy and safety of ASP7962 (a TrkA inhibitor) compared to placebo and naproxen for treating pain in adults with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: ASP7962 showed no significant improvement in pain or physical function compared to placebo, while naproxen demonstrated statistically significant benefits. ASP7962 was safe and well-tolerated.
population_specificity: Adults with painful knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 100 mg twice daily (BID) for ASP7962; 500 mg BID for naproxen.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare functional recovery and changes in morbidity status between two surgical treatments (proximal femoral nail and hemiarthroplasty) for unstable intertrochanteric fractures in elderly patients.
results_summary: The study found that hemiarthroplasty (HA) allowed for early mobilization and decreased dependency but was associated with greater blood loss, higher need for transfusion, longer surgical duration, and a higher proportion of increased morbidity (CIRS scores) at 3-month follow-up compared to proximal femoral nail (PFN).
population_specificity: Patients aged over 80 years with unstable intertrochanteric fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between rehabilitation therapies (including structured play/recreation and health/well-being focus) and developmental outcomes, such as walking endurance, in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: Family-centered therapies that met children's needs and focused on structured play/recreation or health/well-being were associated with greater participation and walking endurance improvements. The amount of therapy did not predict outcomes.
population_specificity: 656 children with cerebral palsy (ages 1y 6mo–11y 11mo; 287 females, 369 males).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare free-living mobility (physical activity and turning) between healthy individuals and those with chronic mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) using a wearable IMU.
results_summary: The study found that while chronic mTBI participants had similar quantities of mobility (macro-level) as controls, they exhibited impaired quality of mobility (micro-level), including larger turns, longer turning durations, and slower velocities during walking bouts.
population_specificity: 23 healthy controls (48.56 ± 23.07 years) and 29 symptomatic chronic mTBI participants (40.2 ± 12.1 years, average 419 days post-injury with persistent balance complaints).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare gait parameters between patients who underwent anatomical hip reconstruction versus high hip center reconstruction after total hip arthroplasty for severe dysplasia.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in gait characteristics between the two surgical techniques, with similar temporospatial, kinematic, and kinetic values. The only notable but statistically insignificant difference was a lower peak dynamic hip extension in the high hip center group.
population_specificity: 20 patients (40 hips) with bilateral Crowe type III-IV developmental dysplasia of the hip who underwent bilateral total hip arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors determining exercise capacity, particularly walking distance (6MWD), in elderly heart failure patients with and without sarcopenia.
results_summary: Walking speed was an independent factor determining 6MWD in both groups, while knee extensor muscle strength was an independent factor only in the sarcopenia group. The study highlighted the importance of muscle strength in exercise capacity for elderly HF patients with sarcopenia.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (>60 years) with heart failure, divided into sarcopenia and nonsarcopenia groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of protein supplementation (PS) combined with muscle strengthening exercise (MSE) in improving lean mass (LM) and physical outcomes in elderly patients at high risk of sarcopenia or frailty.
results_summary: The study found that PS + MSE significantly improved whole-body lean mass (SMD = 0.66) in elderly patients, indicating a clinically meaningful effect. The meta-analysis of 19 RCTs supported the efficacy of this combined intervention.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with a high risk of sarcopenia or frailty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a knee valgus unloader brace affects medial femoral articular cartilage deformation during a 5000-step walking protocol in individuals with varus-knee alignment.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in cartilage deformation between braced and unbraced conditions overall, but suggested the brace might reduce deformation in individuals who normally experience measurable deformation during walking.
population_specificity: 24 healthy individuals (63% female, BMI = 22 ± 3 kg/m²) with varus-knee alignment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to predict functional outcomes 6 months after ankle fracture in people aged ≥60 years using post-treatment and 6-week follow-up data to inform recovery and identify those needing additional monitoring or rehabilitation.
results_summary: The prognostic models using baseline and 6-week data explained only 23-26% of variation in self-reported ankle function and 30-32% in objectively measured function, indicating low predictive accuracy for clinical use. The study concluded that other predictors, such as psychological factors, should be investigated to improve accuracy.
population_specificity: Adults aged 60-96 years (74% female) treated for unstable ankle fractures in UK hospitals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a 5-week Parkinson's disease-specific exercise program provided sustained physical and psychosocial benefits and the relationship between patient characteristics, exercise, falls, and physical/psychosocial outcomes.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in physical measures (e.g., walking distance, balance) and psychosocial measures (e.g., quality of life, depression) at 6 weeks, with physical benefits sustained at 12 months. The number of patients experiencing falls decreased, and lack of exercise correlated with poorer outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with mild-to-moderate Parkinson's disease (n=135).
study_duration: 5 weeks (with follow-up at 6 weeks and 12 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Robot Suit HAL treatment (HAL-T) is safe and feasible for improving gait disorders in adolescents and adults with cerebral palsy (CP).
results_summary: HAL-T significantly improved comfortable gait speed, step length, and cadence in participants with CP, with no severe adverse events reported. The treatment was deemed safe and feasible for this population.
population_specificity: Adolescents and adults with bilateral spastic CP (8 participants, mean age 18.2 years, GMFCS levels III and IV).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of progressive resistance training (PRT) and balance and motor control training (BMCT) on gait performance and fatigue impact in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: BMCT improved gait performance (T25FW, SSST) and self-perceived gait function compared to the control group, while PRT did not. Both BMCT and PRT reduced fatigue impact. BMCT was superior to PRT in dynamic balance, while PRT was superior in knee extensor muscle strength.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) and impaired mobility (T25FW > 5 seconds or SSST > 8 seconds).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a home-based physiotherapy program (PDSAFE) could reduce repeat falls in people with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The PDSAFE program did not significantly reduce repeat falls overall within 6 months but improved balance, confidence, and reduced near-falls. Benefits varied by disease severity, with moderate cases showing fewer falls and severe cases experiencing more falls despite improved balance.
population_specificity: People with Parkinson's disease (Hoehn and Yahr stages 1-4), living at home, able to walk, with at least one fall in the previous year.
effective_dosage: Individually tailored, progressive home-based exercises and fall avoidance strategies (frequency not specified).
study_duration: 6 months (primary outcome), with some assessments at 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether individuals with sports concussion exhibited persistent gait and balance impairments during dual-task assessments compared to non-injured controls.
results_summary: The study found that individuals with recent sports concussion walked slower and exhibited gait impairments during dual-task assessments, persisting beyond standard recovery timelines of 7-10 days. Dual-task assessment with motion capture was suggested as a useful clinical tool for evaluating post-concussion recovery.
population_specificity: Individuals with sports concussion and non-injured controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if pre-operative walking improves post-operative gastrointestinal function recovery in gynecologic cancer surgery patients.
results_summary: Walking before surgery significantly reduced time to first flatus and defecation and lowered the risk of post-operative paralytic ileus compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients with endometrial or ovarian cancer scheduled for comprehensive staging surgery.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes at an average speed of 3 km/h, twice on the last night before surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the difference in 6-minute walk performance between persons with multiple sclerosis (MS) and healthy controls, and within MS subgroups based on disability status.
results_summary: Persons with MS walked a significantly shorter distance than healthy controls (mean difference = -177.2 m, large effect size d = -1.87). Those with mild disability walked further than those with moderate-to-severe disability (mean difference = 185.19 m, large effect size d = 1.83), with encouragement and course layout moderating the effects.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (MS) and healthy controls (HCs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, safety, and effectiveness of an Adapted Physical Activity (APA) protocol, including walking, on health-related quality of life, fear of falling, pain, and physical performance in women with osteoporosis-related vertebral fractures.
results_summary: The exercise group showed significant improvements in health-related quality of life, fear of falling, balance, gait, and functional exercise capacity, with large effect sizes, while the control group remained unchanged. The program demonstrated good adherence (75.8%) and no injuries.
population_specificity: Post-menopausal women (mean age 67.6 ± 4.6) with osteoporotic vertebral fractures.
effective_dosage: Not specified (protocol included postural and muscular reinforcement exercises, likely incorporating walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether wearing textured insoles for 4 weeks improves balance performance in adults with diabetic peripheral neuropathy.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, and results are not yet available (pre-results). The abstract outlines the methodology but does not report findings.
population_specificity: Adults with diabetic peripheral neuropathy, aged ≥18 years, able to walk at least 20 meters (with or without assistive devices).
effective_dosage: Textured or smooth insoles worn daily for 4 weeks (specific duration per day not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Hybrid Assistive Limb (HAL) gait training compared to conventional physical therapy (CP) in improving functional outcomes for patients with acute stroke.
results_summary: The HAL group showed a higher total Functional Independence Measure (FIM) score at the 2nd assessment (90.1 vs. 79.0, p = 0.042) compared to the CP group, indicating better functional recovery. The study concluded that the FIM scale could identify responsiveness to HAL-assisted rehabilitation in acute stroke patients.
population_specificity: Patients with first-ever stroke, requiring a walking aid, and able to start gait training within 1 week of stroke onset (median age = 69 years).
study_duration: Gait training with HAL until the 2nd assessment (2-6 weeks); overall physical therapy continued until the 3rd assessment (3-5 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate and validate regression models for predicting ground reaction forces while walking in water, particularly for individuals with lower limb injuries or weight-bearing restrictions.
results_summary: The study found that body mass, immersion ratio, and velocity predicted 95% of vertical and resultant ground reaction force variability, while velocity and thigh circumference explained 81% of antero-posterior force variability. The models showed good predictive performance with high intraclass correlation coefficients (0.88-0.90) and were validated against measured data.
population_specificity: 137 individuals (24±5 years, 1.71±0.08 m, 68.7±12.5 kg) with potential lower limb injuries or weight-bearing restrictions.
effective_dosage: Not specified (self-selected walking speed in water depths of 0.75 to 1.35 m).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of lifestyle changes, including walking exercise, on psoriasis severity and quality of life.
results_summary: One trial assessed walking exercise and continuous health education in 200 participants, but severity outcomes were not reported. The study did not provide specific efficacy data for walking alone.
population_specificity: 200 participants with psoriasis (mean age: 43.1 years; severity not reported).
study_duration: Not specified (treatment periods in the review ranged from 12 weeks to 3 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of postprandial walking versus rest on metabolic, inflammatory, and oxidative responses after consuming different meal types (Western vs. Mediterranean) in older adults at increased CVD risk.
results_summary: Walking did not significantly differ from resting in most postprandial outcomes, though it increased plasma IL-6 and vitamin C levels. The Mediterranean diet showed superior effects on triglycerides and other parameters compared to the Western diet, but no meal × activity interactions were significant.
population_specificity: Older adults (aged 70 ± 5 y; BMI 30.3 ± 2.3 kg/m²) with increased CVD risk (26 participants).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of walking at 4.6 ± 0.1 km/h post-meal.
study_duration: Acute effects measured over 4.5 hours postprandially.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the effectiveness of the Gait Exercise Assist Robot (GEAR) in improving walking ability in subacute stroke patients with hemiplegia.
results_summary: The GEAR group showed significantly higher FIM-walk improvement efficiency and score gain after 4 weeks compared to the control group, though differences were not sustained at 8 weeks or discharge. GEAR contributed to early walking improvement through optimized training mechanisms.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients with hemiplegia admitted to comprehensive inpatient rehabilitation wards.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved gait training with GEAR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate contextual effects (placebo responses) for patient-reported and objectively measured function, including walking, in osteoarthritis clinical trials.
results_summary: The study found that placebo responses for function outcomes (including walking time/distance) were generally lower than for pain measures, with walking time/distance showing the smallest (most favorable) placebo response ratio. The results support including physical function measures in OA trials to enhance success rates.
