population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis (hip and knee OA) in randomized, placebo-controlled trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on the effects of environmental interventions targeting walking and cycling, and to understand how and why these interventions may or may not be effective.
results_summary: The study found that 70% of evaluations scored low on credibility for effectiveness, but higher-quality evaluations were more likely to report positive effects. The most effective interventions targeted accessibility and safety in both supportive and unsupportive contexts.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from environmental intervention focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining regular walking exercise with positive education improves cardiovascular fitness and happiness more than walking alone in retired older adults.
results_summary: The study found that participants who combined walking with positive education (PEPWET) had higher rates of regular walking, better cardiovascular fitness, and greater happiness compared to those who only walked (PWE). The PEPWET group also showed significantly higher happiness scores than the walking-only training group (PWET).
population_specificity: Retired older adults
effective_dosage: 45 minutes per session, three times per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the reliability of non-operative treatment (including early walking) for Garden I femoral neck fractures in patients over 65 years old, identifying predictors of secondary displacement and treatment failure.
results_summary: Non-operative treatment was effective in 66% of patients, with secondary displacement occurring in 30%. Risk factors for displacement included dementia, institutionalization, hypnotic treatment, multiple comorbidities, and repeated falls. Community-dwelling patients with normal cognition and no repeated falls had an 88% success rate with non-operative treatment.
population_specificity: Patients older than 65 years with Garden I femoral neck fractures managed non-operatively.
effective_dosage: Walking test on day 1 post-fracture, followed by radiographs at specified intervals.
interactions: Hypnotic treatment was associated with increased risk of secondary displacement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and impact of a program involving relatives in postoperative care, focusing on activities like walking, breathing exercises, and cognitive tasks.
results_summary: Patients in the intervention group walked more (170 meters per day), adhered better to breathing exercises, oral hygiene, and cognitive activities, and reported higher satisfaction. Relatives felt better prepared for discharge and recommended the program.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing esophageal or pancreatic resection at a University hospital in the Netherlands, with participating relatives.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness and safety of drug-coated balloon angioplasty for infrapopliteal atherosclerotic lesions in patients with critical limb ischaemia.
results_summary: The study found significant clinical improvement in Rutherford category, walking impairment questionnaire scores, quality of life, and pain reduction at 6 and 12 months, with high primary patency and amputation-free survival rates.
population_specificity: Patients with critical limb ischaemia (average age 74.7 years), predominantly with diabetes mellitus (79.9%) and renal insufficiency (57.3%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical outcomes of bilateral lung transplantation (BLT) and single lung transplantation (SLT), including survival rates, pulmonary function, and complications.
results_summary: The study found that BLT was associated with better long-term survival, improved postoperative lung function, and less bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome (BOS) compared to SLT, though in-hospital mortality and non-BOS complications were similar between the two groups.
population_specificity: Lung transplant recipients (1980 SLT and 2112 BLT patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of ONO-4474 in reducing knee pain during walking in Japanese patients with osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study assessed knee pain during walking using a visual analog scale (VAS) over 24 hours, but specific results regarding the efficacy of ONO-4474 were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Japanese patients with moderate to severe osteoarthritis of the knee who were refractory to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and clinical application of levodopa-carbidopa intestinal gel (LCIG) for managing motor fluctuations in advanced Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: LCIG significantly reduced "off" time and increased "on" time without troublesome dyskinesia, offering better symptom control compared to oral carbidopa/levodopa due to continuous delivery and bypassing gastric absorption issues. Clinical and observational studies supported its efficacy in managing motor and nonmotor complications.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced Parkinson's disease experiencing motor fluctuations.
effective_dosage: Not specified (continuous infusion via portable pump).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether muscle-targeted nutritional support (whey protein, leucine, and vitamin D) enhances functional outcomes, particularly walking distance, in patients with Parkinson's disease or parkinsonism undergoing intensive rehabilitation.
results_summary: The nutritional supplement significantly increased the distance walked during a 6-minute walking test (mean difference of 18.1 meters) compared to standard diet alone, and also improved lower extremity function and preserved muscle mass.
population_specificity: Cognitively intact patients with Parkinson's disease or parkinsonism undergoing a 30-day multidisciplinary intensive rehabilitation treatment.
effective_dosage: Whey protein-based nutritional supplement enriched with leucine and vitamin D, administered twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether interrupting IL-1β signaling with canakinumab could reduce plaque progression in the superficial femoral artery and improve walking performance in patients with symptomatic PAD.
results_summary: Canakinumab was safe and well-tolerated, reduced systemic inflammation markers, and showed early improvement in maximum and pain-free walking distance, though it did not alter plaque progression in the SFA.
population_specificity: 38 patients (mean age 65 years; 71% male) with symptomatic PAD confirmed by ankle-brachial index.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pharmacological characteristics, efficacy, and adverse effects of quazepam compared to other agents used for insomnia.
results_summary: The abstract highlights quazepam's unique pharmacological properties, such as selectivity for sleep-promoting GABA-A receptors, and suggests it may have a lower rate of adverse events like tolerance and rebound insomnia compared to other benzodiazepines. However, no direct results regarding walking are mentioned.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of insomnia treatments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate current approaches for assessing exertional breathlessness and the need for individualized, standardized assessment methods during exercise, including walking.
results_summary: The study found that constant work rate tests, such as 3-min stair stepping and walking tests, effectively standardize exercise stimuli to directly quantify breathlessness, unlike self-paced or incremental tests. Multidimensional assessment tools are recommended for accurate symptom management and intervention efficacy evaluation.
population_specificity: Chronic disease populations experiencing exertional breathlessness.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and effects of growth hormone (GH) therapy on body composition and walking ability in infants with Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) under 2 years of age.
results_summary: GH treatment improved body composition, with significant reductions in skinfold thickness and trends in height and BMI. Infants who started GH before 15 months began walking earlier (median 18.0 months) compared to those starting after 15 months (median 36.6 months).
population_specificity: Infants with Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) under 2 years of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility and potential efficacy of combining cross-education with mirror therapy versus cross-education alone for lower limb recovery poststroke.
results_summary: Both interventions were well tolerated without adverse effects. Only the combined treatment (strength training with mirror therapy) showed functional improvements, specifically increased walking velocity, while no between-group differences were found for other measures like strength or mobility.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke participants (average age 61.7 ± 13.3 years).
effective_dosage: Unilateral strength training of the less-affected ankle dorsiflexors three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immediate and long-term effects of a group-based, individualized core stability and balance intervention (GroupCoreDIST) compared to standard care on walking in individuals with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: GroupCoreDIST significantly improved walking performance (2MWT, PGIC-walking) immediately after the intervention and maintained benefits for up to 24 weeks, with some improvements also seen in 10MWT-fast speed and MSWS-12 at specific time points. No significant differences were found in activity levels (ActiGraph) or 10MWT-preferred/slow speed.
population_specificity: Individuals with multiple sclerosis (Expanded Disability Status Scale scores 1-6.5).
effective_dosage: 60 minutes, three times per week for 6 weeks (18 sessions total).
study_duration: 6 weeks (with follow-up assessments at Weeks 7, 18, and 30).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether prolonged exposure to optical flow perturbations during walking could promote reactive balance control and increased balance confidence in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that older adults initially responded to perturbations with wider, shorter steps and increased muscle coactivation, but these effects diminished with prolonged exposure. After training, participants exhibited longer, narrower steps and reduced muscle coactivation, suggesting improved reactive control and balance confidence.
population_specificity: Older adults (13 participants)
effective_dosage: 10 minutes of treadmill walking with optical flow perturbations

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether frailty, including slow walking speed, predicts reduced benefit from implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs) in preventing sudden cardiac death.
results_summary: The study found that individuals identified as frail, including those with slow walking speed, had higher mortality rates and did not benefit from ICD therapy. One RCT specifically noted that slow walkers showed no survival benefit from ICDs after 3 years.
population_specificity: Older adults, particularly those with frailty or slow walking speed, and Medicare beneficiaries with ICDs.
study_duration: Follow-up varied from days to over 6 years.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effects of time-restricted feeding (TRF) on weight loss and functional improvements in overweight, sedentary older adults with mobility impairments.
results_summary: The study found high adherence to TRF (84%) and a mean weight loss of 2.6 kg over four weeks, but no specific results related to walking were reported.
population_specificity: Overweight, sedentary older adults (≥65 years) at risk for or with mobility impairments (slow gait speed <1.0 m/s).
effective_dosage: Fasting for approximately 16 hours per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of 4 g n-3 PUFA supplementation on endothelial function, inflammatory markers, and walking distances in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found that 4 g n-3 PUFA daily significantly improved endothelial function (measured by FMD) compared to placebo after 3 months, but this benefit was not sustained after a washout period. No significant changes were observed in other parameters, including walking distances.
population_specificity: Patients with stable PAD (Rutherford stage 2 or 3) and good control of cardiovascular factors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether post-meal uphill or downhill treadmill walking could enhance osteogenic response and improve insulin sensitivity in postmenopausal women with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Post-meal exercise (both uphill and downhill) significantly increased the osteogenic response (CICP/CTX ratio) and lowered serum insulin resistance (HOMA-IR), while pre-meal exercise showed no such effects. The osteogenic response was driven by increased CICP levels rather than reduced CTX levels.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: 40 minutes of treadmill walking (uphill or downhill), performed either before or after two daily meals, with meals and exercise bouts spaced 7 hours apart.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated (likely short-term, given the trial design).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether consumption of MFGM and glucosamine improves joint function and physical performance in older adults with mild knee or low back pain.
results_summary: The active treatment group showed significant improvements in passive and active range of motion at the knee and low back, as well as enhanced physical performance in tasks like obstacle walking and stair ascending.
population_specificity: Healthy Japanese men and women aged 60-74 with a history of mild knee or low back pain at rest.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness and limitations of botulinum toxin type A (BoNT-A) in improving muscle function and gait in children with cerebral palsy, particularly focusing on toe-walking.
results_summary: BoNT-A injections reduced muscle activity and improved range of motion in some children, but gait improvements were inconsistent, small, and short-lived. Long-term muscle atrophy and structural changes were observed, raising concerns about reversibility.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (hemiplegia or diplegia) exhibiting toe-walking.
study_duration: Effects monitored for 3-6 months post-injection, with long-term atrophy noted for at least 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of downslope walking (DSW) on spinal excitability and walking function in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: Acute DSW at -15% grade significantly depressed H-reflexes compared to level walking, and 6 sessions of DSW improved walking function, though no significant changes in spinal excitability were observed. Greater acute H-reflex depression correlated with better physical activity and walking function outcomes.
population_specificity: 12 people with multiple sclerosis (11 women; 45.3±11.8 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of aquatic versus land motor dual task training on balance and gait in patients with chronic stroke.
results_summary: Both aquatic and land training significantly improved balance and gait, but aquatic training showed greater improvements in stability indices, walking speed, step length, and support time on the affected limb.
population_specificity: 50 patients with chronic stroke, aged 45-55 years, of both sexes.
effective_dosage: 45 minutes per session, 3 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of lumbar decompression surgery in patients with spinal epidural lipomatosis (SEL) compared to non-SEL patients, particularly focusing on walking ability.
results_summary: The study found that while both SEL and non-SEL groups showed significant improvements in walking ability post-surgery, the SEL group had worse outcomes, with a higher risk of "not effective" results at 1 and 2 years postoperatively.
population_specificity: 288 patients with lumbar spinal canal stenosis, including 60 with SEL and 60 matched non-SEL patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety, efficacy, and optimal dosage of botulinum toxin (BTX) injections for calf muscle contouring without disrupting walking or running.
results_summary: All subjects showed clinical improvement in gastrocnemius muscle size reduction after BTX injection, but the effect was not dose-dependent. No adverse effects, such as leg weakness, deformity, or infection, were observed.
population_specificity: 40 patients with bilateral gastrocnemius muscle hypertrophy.
effective_dosage: 160 U and 200 U administered on medial and lateral aspects of calves.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Kinect-based exergaming and combined exercise on improving frailty status and physical performance in prefrail and frail elderly.
results_summary: Both exergaming and combined exercise improved frailty status and reversed three out of five frailty phenotype characteristics (weakness, slow walking speed, and low activity level). Exergaming also reversed exhaustion and showed greater improvement in dynamic balance control compared to combined exercise.
population_specificity: Prefrail and frail elderly individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of stem cell treatment on rotator cuff healing, including its impact on walking distance, time, and speed.
results_summary: The stem cell group showed significantly superior walking distance, time, and speed compared to the control group, indicating improved rehabilitation outcomes for rotator cuff disorders.
population_specificity: Patients with rotator cuff disorders
study_duration: Outcomes measured at 4, 8, and 16 weeks, with walking metrics assessed up to 6 months

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether age-related small vessel white matter disease (SVD) in the brain causes dizziness in elderly patients by disrupting neural connectivity.
results_summary: The study proposed that SVD leads to dizziness through disconnection of vestibular, gait, and motor-sensory pathways, supported by preliminary EEG data and a literature review.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with "unexplained" dizziness and signs of small vessel white matter disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether active para-spinal transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) was more effective than de-tuned TENS in improving walking ability in patients with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
results_summary: Both active and de-tuned TENS groups showed significant improvement in walking distance, but there was no significant difference between the two groups. Active TENS was not superior to de-tuned TENS for improving walking ability in LSS patients.
population_specificity: 104 participants aged 50 or older with neurogenic claudication, imaging-confirmed LSS, and limited walking ability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term health outcomes of two primary care pedometer-based walking interventions (PACE-UP and PACE-Lift) on cardiovascular events, diabetes, depression, fractures, and falls.
results_summary: The study found significantly fewer new cardiovascular events and fractures in intervention participants at 4 years, with no statistically significant differences for diabetes, depression, or falls. Short-term walking interventions demonstrated long-term health benefits, particularly for cardiovascular health and fracture prevention.
population_specificity: Adults aged 45-75 years (PACE-UP) and older adults aged 60-75 years (PACE-Lift) from primary care practices.
study_duration: 12-week intervention with follow-up at 3 and 4 years.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the safety and efficacy of ivacaftor in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF) and severe lung disease, specifically those with non-G551D gating mutations.
results_summary: The study found that ivacaftor was safe and effective in CF patients with severe lung disease and non-G551D gating mutations, with improvements in lung function (ppFEV1) observed.
population_specificity: Patients with cystic fibrosis and severe lung disease (non-G551D gating mutations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of supervised exercise therapy (SET), home-based exercise therapy (HBET), and endovascular revascularisation (ER) on daily physical activity in patients with intermittent claudication (IC).
results_summary: Both SET and HBET showed a significant increase in daily physical activity compared to usual care, with SET adding 803 steps/day and HBET adding 980 steps/day. ER did not show a statistically significant improvement in physical activity compared to control.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication (IC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of overground gait training with and without rhythmic auditory stimulation (RAS) on walking velocity, capacity, balance, and stride length in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: Both gait training interventions (with and without RAS) improved walking velocity, capacity, balance, and stride length, but there were no significant differences between the two groups. The improvements were modest and not clinically distinct.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (mean age 67 years, 9 females, all left-sided strokes, mean illness duration 67 months).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes, three times a week for 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and effects of EMG-biofeedback-assisted robotic treadmill training on walking and cardiopulmonary function in individuals with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in walking performance, mobility, bilateral symmetry, and cardiopulmonary function compared to the control group, which received passive lower limb mobilization.
population_specificity: Individuals with incomplete spinal cord injury (n=16).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the effectiveness of cycling (with/without functional electrical stimulation) on functional mobility, including walking speed and balance, in stroke survivors.
results_summary: Cycling improved 6-meter walking test performance, 10-meter walking speed, and balance (Berg score). Functional electrical stimulation combined with cycling further enhanced balance compared to cycling alone.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of balloon pulmonary angioplasty (BPA) in treating chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH).
results_summary: BPA was associated with significant improvements in hemodynamic parameters, including reduced mean pulmonary artery pressure and pulmonary vascular resistance, and increased cardiac index. The procedure was deemed relatively safe, with adverse events reported but not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH) who were inoperable or had persistent symptoms after pulmonary endoarteriectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors related to the decline in physical functioning (specifically gait speed) after cardiac surgery in older patients.
results_summary: The study found that 17% of patients experienced a postoperative decline in gait speed, with age, kidney function, preoperative gait speed, and time to regain independent walking being significant predictors. The results suggest potential targets for rehabilitation interventions to mitigate functional decline.
population_specificity: Older patients (≥65 years) who underwent cardiac surgery and could walk independently before and after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether physical exercise, including Nordic or power walking, improves cognitive functioning and brain measures in chemotherapy-exposed breast cancer patients with cognitive problems.
results_summary: The study design includes a 6-month exercise intervention combining aerobic, strength exercises, and walking, but the abstract does not report specific results on walking's effects yet. Outcomes will be measured at baseline, 6 months, and 18 months.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients with cognitive problems 2-4 years after diagnosis.
effective_dosage: Twice a week 1-hour Nordic or power walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a web-based nursing intervention (TAVIE en m@rche) could increase daily walking steps in insufficiently active acute coronary syndrome patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect on daily steps (primary outcome) but noted a non-significant increase in moderate to vigorous physical activity (MVPA) energy expenditure in the intervention group. No effects were observed for angina frequency, emergency visits, hospitalizations, or secondary prevention attendance.
population_specificity: Acute coronary syndrome patients who were insufficiently active, recruited from three coronary care units.

study_goal: The study aimed to determine the effects of acupressure on quality of life and dyspnea level for individuals with lung cancer, not walking.
results_summary: The study found that acupressure significantly reduced dyspnea and improved quality of life in lung cancer patients, but it did not assess walking.
population_specificity: Lung cancer patients receiving chemotherapy and experiencing dyspnea.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (acupressure was applied 2 times per day for 4 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine physical activity preferences, particularly walking, associated with increased moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) and reduced sedentary time in Mexican American women.
results_summary: The study found significant increases in MVPA and decreases in sedentary time associated with leisure, errand, and brisk walking, as well as other aerobic activities. Effect sizes for walking-related activities were statistically significant, indicating meaningful improvements in physical activity levels.
population_specificity: Low-income Mexican American women living on the U.S.-Mexico border.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether financial incentives could effectively increase the number of daily steps among physically inactive, community-dwelling adults in Japan.
results_summary: The study is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) designed to measure the average increase in daily steps at 4-6 weeks and 7-9 weeks compared to baseline, assuming a difference of 1,302 steps. Results are pending as the abstract states "Pre-results."
population_specificity: Community-dwelling, physically inactive adults in Nakayama, a suburban area of Sendai city, Japan.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involves financial incentives for increased steps).
study_duration: Primary outcomes measured at 4-6 weeks and 7-9 weeks relative to baseline (1-3 weeks).

study_goal: To examine the effects of home-based interval walking on aerobic and metabolic fitness and quality of life in patients with colorectal cancer.
results_summary: Interval walking significantly improved postprandial glycemic control, counteracted fat gain, and improved the Matsuda index, but had no effect on VO2peak.
population_specificity: Sedentary patients with stage I to III colorectal cancer who had completed primary treatment.
effective_dosage: 150 minutes per week of home-based interval walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of functional training and traditional training on joint mobility, gait determinants, and muscle strength in older women, and to assess the maintenance of these effects after detraining.
results_summary: Both functional training and traditional training improved muscle strength and power, but functional training showed additional benefits in dynamic agility/balance and cardiorespiratory condition compared to stretching. The effects were maintained after eight weeks of detraining.
population_specificity: Older women (52 participants, aged not specified)
study_duration: Eight and twelve weeks of intervention, followed by eight weeks of detraining

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of conducting a definitive trial for the BRiMS program, which combines exercise and education to improve balance and mobility in people with secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS).
results_summary: The study found that the BRiMS program was feasible and acceptable, with participants reporting improved balance and fewer falls, though adherence to the program was suboptimal. The trial design was deemed suitable for a larger-scale study, but modifications to the program's educational content were recommended.
population_specificity: People with secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS), EDSS scores 4.0-7.0, and a history of two or more falls in the preceding 6 months.
effective_dosage: Not specified (13-week education and exercise program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of walking and hula-hooping, matched for energy expenditure, on android fat percentage, trunk muscle mass, and metabolic parameters in overweight subjects.
results_summary: Walking did not significantly reduce android fat percentage but lowered systolic blood pressure and increased HDL cholesterol. It was less effective than hula-hooping in reducing waist circumference and increasing trunk muscle mass.
population_specificity: Overweight nondiabetic subjects (waist 92 ± 1 cm, BMI 28 ± 1 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether MS type and rehabilitation setting (inpatient vs. outpatient) influenced the effectiveness of balance rehabilitation, particularly focusing on specific vs. non-specific interventions.
results_summary: Balance improved significantly after rehabilitation, with clinically meaningful improvements more likely in individuals with moderate to high disability who received specific balance exercises. MS type did not influence outcomes, but low baseline balance scores and specific treatment were associated with better results.
population_specificity: 150 people with progressive or relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the most sensitive clinical measure of improvement in exercise capacity or lung function in adults with severe cystic fibrosis (FEV1 < 40% predicted) treated with Lumacaftor/Ivacaftor (LUM/IVA).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in the six-minute walk test (6MWT) by 4 weeks, with further increases at 52 weeks, along with improvements in resting heart rate and oxygen saturation during walking. No significant improvements were observed in FEV1 until 24 weeks, though this was maintained at 52 weeks.
population_specificity: Adults homozygous for the Phe508del gene with severe cystic fibrosis (FEV1 < 40% predicted).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether walking is more effective than yoga at improving sleep disturbance in cancer patients.
results_summary: Walking significantly improved sleep disturbance compared to yoga (p = 0.01), with adherence rate and outcome measurement tools identified as significant moderators. Moderate-intensity walking was the most frequently used intervention and was recommended for cancer patients with sleep disturbance.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients (majority) and other cancer patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and advantages of riociguat compared to other drugs targeting the NO pathway in treating pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), particularly its impact on improving physical activity (6-minute walking distance).
results_summary: Riociguat significantly improved the 6-minute walking distance in PAH patients (mean difference of 36 m vs. placebo), with comparable results to tadalafil and sildenafil. It showed potential superiority in patients with insufficient endogenous NO production and exhibited anti-proliferative, anti-inflammatory, and anti-fibrotic effects in animal models.
population_specificity: Patients suffering from pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Trimetazidine (TMZ) in improving muscle function, including gait speed and walking distance, in individuals with poor muscle performance.
results_summary: The study assessed TMZ's impact on 6-minute walking distance, muscle strength, gait speed, endurance, balance, and angina frequency, but results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with low handgrip strength and declining gait speed, also receiving conventional angina treatments.
effective_dosage: 35 mg of oral TMZ twice daily with meals.

study_goal: To assess the benefits and harms of rigid dressings versus soft dressings for treating transtibial amputations, particularly in wound healing and functional outcomes.
results_summary: The study found very low-certainty evidence that rigid dressings may decrease time to wound healing compared to soft dressings, but no clear superiority in wound healing rates, adverse events, prosthetic prescription, walking function, or hospital stay.
population_specificity: People with transtibial amputations, primarily due to vascular conditions, from acute and rehabilitation hospitals in seven countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of udenafil (50 mg BID) in improving exercise capacity, measured by 6-min walking distance, in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension.
results_summary: Udenafil showed a modest improvement in 6-min walking distance (25 m placebo-corrected, P=0.0873), with a more significant effect (34 m, P=0.0460) in patients with prior endothelin receptor antagonist therapy. No significant differences were observed in Borg dyspnea score or time to clinical worsening.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (n=63).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association of motoric cognitive risk syndrome (MCR) and its components (slow walking speed and subjective cognitive complaints) with falls, recurrent falls, and postfall fractures in older community-dwelling adults.
results_summary: The study found that MCR was associated with a significantly higher risk for falls, recurrent falls, and postfall hip fractures, but not its individual components (slow walking speed or subjective cognitive complaints alone).
population_specificity: Older community-dwelling women (n = 5958) from the EPIDOS study in France.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify modifiable predictors of pain interference, including infrequent walking, and estimate the potential impact of interventions targeting these factors in adults with joint pain.
results_summary: Infrequent walking was independently associated with the onset of pain interference after 3 years, with a statistically significant population attributable risk (PAR) of 8.0%. The combined PAR for infrequent walking, insomnia, and inadequate pain control was 20.3%.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥50 years with joint pain lasting ≥3 months and no baseline pain interference, recruited from general practices in North Staffordshire, UK.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a two-month breathing-based walking intervention on anxiety, depression, dyspnoea, and quality of life in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: The walking group showed significant improvements in anxiety, depression, dyspnoea, and quality of life over three months compared to the control group and baseline measurements. The intervention was feasible and acceptable for COPD outpatients.
population_specificity: Outpatients diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) from a medical center in Taiwan.
effective_dosage: Breathing, meditation, and walking for two months (specific frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Two months (with follow-up measurements at Month 3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercise (including walking) after percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) improves heart function and reduces adverse cardiovascular events in patients with coronary heart disease (CHD).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that exercise significantly improved left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) and reduced the incidence of cardiac death, myocardial infarction, coronary angioplasty, angina pectoris, and restenosis. However, no significant differences were observed in left ventricular end diastolic diameter (LVEDD), 6-minute walking distance (6MWD), or coronary artery bypass surgery (CABG).
population_specificity: Patients with coronary heart disease (CHD) who underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a self-determination theory-based physical activity intervention (including walking) could effectively promote behavior change and increase physical activity levels in older adults with bowel polyps.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in behavioral regulation and physical activity (including walking) for the intervention group compared to standard care at 6 months, with effects favoring the active lifestyle program.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 69 years) diagnosed with bowel polyps.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of oral iron supplementation (ferrous fumarate or ferric hydroxide polymaltose complex) on the prognosis of chronic heart failure (CHF) and quality of life, measured by the 6-minute walking test (6MWT).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in hemoglobin levels, 6MWT distance, and New York Heart Association class after 6 months of iron supplementation in both groups, indicating improved quality of life for CHF patients with iron deficiency.
population_specificity: 201 patients with chronic decompensated heart failure.
effective_dosage: Not specified (ferrous fumarate for group I, ferric hydroxide polymaltose complex for group II).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term clinical outcomes of four different cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) optimization methods, including their effects on walking distance (6MWD).
results_summary: At 6 months, the nominal CRT group showed significantly shorter 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) compared to the other three optimization methods (ECHO, ECG, QuickOpt), but no significant differences were observed at 12, 24, or 48 months.
population_specificity: 124 patients with severe heart failure and left bundle-branch block configuration.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (CRT optimization methods, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to define and compare the clinical profiles and outcomes of low iron storage (LIS) and defective iron utilization (DIU) in patients with heart failure (HF).
results_summary: The study found that both LIS and DIU were prevalent in HF patients, with LIS associated with poorer quality of life and higher rates of mortality or HF hospitalizations, while DIU was linked to higher inflammatory markers. Both conditions were associated with impaired 6-minute walking test performance.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure, including those with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (≤45%) and worsening HF from multinational cohorts.
study_duration: Median follow-up of 1.8 years (interquartile range 1.3-2.3 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare knee pain during walking and other activities between patients who underwent tibial nailing via suprapatellar (SP) or infrapatellar (IP) approaches.
results_summary: The study found no statistically or clinically significant differences in knee pain during walking (IP: 2.7, SP: 3.0; P = 0.51) or other activities between the two surgical approaches.
population_specificity: Tibia fracture patients aged 18-80 years treated with intramedullary tibial nailing at an academic Level I trauma center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT) and custom foot orthotics (CFO) in treating plantar fasciitis-related pain and foot function.
results_summary: Both ESWT and CFO significantly improved morning and evening pain, foot function, and foot health at 4, 12, and 24 weeks. CFO showed sustained improvement at 48 weeks, while ESWT did not maintain significance in some parameters. Neither treatment was superior to the other.
population_specificity: 83 patients with plantar fasciitis, divided into ESWT (n=40) and CFO (n=43) groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-depressive and health effects of add-on exercise (running therapy or Nordic walking) in patients with Major Depressive Disorder (MDD).
results_summary: The study found no significant anti-depressive effect of the exercise intervention (Cohen's d < 0.2), but large effect sizes were observed for improved aerobic capacity (VO2). The high drop-out rate and small sample size limited the study's power.
population_specificity: Patients with Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) recruited from specialized mental health care institutions.
effective_dosage: Exercise planned two times a week.
study_duration: 6 months (though analysis was limited to the first 3 months due to high drop-out rates).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a home-based walking exercise program with monthly reinforcement sessions provided additional long-term functional benefits compared to usual care after a 4-week outpatient cardiac rehabilitation program in elderly patients.
results_summary: Both the control and treatment groups showed similar improvements in functional outcomes after the initial 4-week rehabilitation. The home-based walking program did not provide additional long-term benefits beyond the conventional rehabilitation program.
population_specificity: Elderly patients aged 75 years and older with various indications for cardiac rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: Standardized set of home-based exercises with monthly center-based reinforcements for the first 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility of using home-based virtual reality training (VRT) for rehabilitation post-stroke, focusing on standing balance, stepping, and walking.
results_summary: The study assessed the feasibility of home-based VRT and outcome measures but did not report specific efficacy results for walking; effect sizes were planned for calculation.
population_specificity: Forty patients post-stroke who could stand for at least 2 minutes, soon to be discharged from inpatient or outpatient rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of exercise 5 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the neurophysiological mechanisms underlying gait improvement in Parkinson's disease patients using Rhythmic Auditory Stimulation (RAS) during treadmill training.
results_summary: RAS gait training showed greater improvements in clinical, kinematic, and electrophysiological measures compared to non-RAS training, including enhanced sensorimotor rhythms and connectivity, suggesting RAS reshapes internal timing mechanisms to improve gait performance.
population_specificity: 50 patients with idiopathic Parkinson's disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether changes in dual-task walking capacity mediate the positive effects of Tai Ji Quan and multimodal exercise on physical performance, cognition, and falls in older adults at high risk of falling.
results_summary: Tai Ji Quan significantly improved dual-task walking capacity, leading to better physical performance, activity confidence, cognitive function, and fewer falls, while multimodal exercise improved physical performance and balance confidence but did not affect dual-task cost.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults older than 70 years with a history of falls or impaired mobility.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the degree of disability in pulmonary hypertension (PH) patients, particularly focusing on mobility and life activities, using the WHODAS 2.0 questionnaire.
results_summary: The study found mild to moderate disability in mobility and life activities among PH patients, with disability scores proportional to PH severity. Baseline WHODAS 2.0 scores showed significant associations with disease progression, though not all domains were equally affected.
population_specificity: Patients with documented pulmonary hypertension (N = 46).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of goal-setting interventions, including walking, for patients with multimorbidity in general practice.
results_summary: Participants set goals related to walking among other subjects, found the intervention acceptable, and desired more frequent follow-up. The study did not specifically measure walking outcomes but noted general patient satisfaction and GP approval of the goal-setting approach.
population_specificity: Adults with two or more long-term health conditions at risk of unplanned hospital admission (mean age ~80 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether using the Settner shoe for early mobilization improves quality of life and physical activity in patients with calcaneus fractures within the first 3 months.
results_summary: The study hypothesizes that the Settner shoe enables early mobilization, potentially improving quality of life and physical activity, with secondary outcomes including return-to-work time, gait analysis, and quality-of-life metrics. Results are pending as it is a randomized controlled trial in progress.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18-60 years with calcaneus fractures, either one-sided or two-sided.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of the built environment on patient falls in hospital rooms, including elements related to walking aids.
results_summary: The study identified 30 articles examining environmental factors like walking aids, but the level of evidence was insufficient for robust conclusions. More research is needed to develop actionable interventions.
population_specificity: Patients in hospital rooms (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare walking neuromechanics (kinematics, muscle activity, and kinetics) between individuals with chronic ankle instability (CAI) and healthy controls to identify potential maladaptive gait patterns.
results_summary: The CAI group exhibited altered gait neuromechanics, including increased plantar flexion, inversion, and hip-flexion angles, modified joint moments and powers, and changes in muscle activation, suggesting a hip-dominant strategy to compensate for ankle limitations. These differences may indicate maladaptive gait patterns contributing to recurrent sprains or predisposing individuals to initial injuries.
population_specificity: 100 participants with CAI (49 men, 51 women; age 22.2 ± 2.3 years) and 100 healthy controls (55 men, 45 women; age 22.5 ± 3.3 years).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking trials, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of a home-delivered behavior-change intervention (MOSAIC) to increase walking in people with intermittent claudication (IC).
results_summary: The MOSAIC trial was feasible to conduct, with high participant retention (92%) and adherence (71%), though missing pedometer data was a limitation. The intervention was acceptable to participants and clinicians, suggesting potential for facilitating walking in IC patients.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥18 years diagnosed with intermittent claudication (IC) identified from vascular outpatient clinics (mean age: 66.8 ± 9.4 years, 79% male).
effective_dosage: Two 60-minute home-based sessions and two 20-minute booster telephone calls incorporating behavior-change techniques.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal first-line treatment for intermittent claudication by comparing best medical therapy, percutaneous angioplasty, supervised exercise therapy, and their combinations.
results_summary: PTA combined with SET was superior to other treatments, improving maximum walking distance by 290 m and quality of life (Cohen's D = 1.8). The study concluded that PTA plus SET is the optimal first-line strategy for IC.
population_specificity: 2,983 patients with intermittent claudication (mean age 68 years, 54.5% men).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of supervised exercise training (SET) on cardiovascular risk factors and walking capacity in patients with intermittent claudication (IC).
results_summary: SET significantly improved pain-free walking distance (+132 m) and maximum walking distance (+183 m) but showed limited effects on cardiovascular risk factors, with only systolic blood pressure showing a modest reduction (-5.8 mmHg).
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication (mean age 66.3 years; mean ankle brachial index, 0.64).
effective_dosage: Not specified (various exercise modalities: walking, resistance, aerobic, or combined training).
